passages.text: Clients tell us that their most valuable counterparts are those who successfully differentiate signal from noise. Aimed to provide clarity around the particularly busy period of reporting, Forward Focus is our published reference for upcoming earnings, including all upcoming events and our analysts' views into them, in one place. It highlights the key metrics our analysts have identified as most relevant for each of the reporting events in the two weeks ahead, their estimates for those key metrics and a link to their preview. You can also find a complete list of all stocks our analysts have placed on Positive or Negative Catalyst Watch into an upcoming event. Analyst contact details are here, Meet the Teams if you have further questions or would like to discuss. The publication is also available in an excel version here.
Positive Catalyst Watch: International Consolidated Airlines Group SA, Siemens AG, Smith & Nephew PLC, Smurfit WestRock PLC, voestalpine AG, Volvo AB
Negative Catalyst Watch:Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Softcat PLC, Traton SE

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

CWCompany, Analyst, SectorEventKey MetricsJPMePreviewAnalyst CommentaryInPost (OW)S1Adjusted EBITDA (PLN mn)1,887.23LinkWe expect a solid financial performance for Q2 with adj. EBITDA of PLN 947mn and reported EBIT of PLN 547mn, with a total parcel volume growth of 22%.Alexia DoganiTransport &amp; LogisticsOxford Nanopore (OW)S1H1'25 Revenues* (€m)100.80LinkAt the H1'25 Trading update, ONT reported H1'25 Revenues of €105m, 5% ahead of Company Consensus and 4% ahead of JPMe. Gross Profit margin was "marginally below H1'24 at 58.8%", with a non-cash one-off charge related to inventory and FX headwinds offsetting measures to improve GM, and increased adoption of CapEx purchases by customers. If we assume a GM of 58.0%, this would imply GP of c. €61m, c. 4% ahead of cons. and 3% ahead of JPMe. If we were to assume the one-off inventory charge was -€2.4m, this would imply an underlying GM of -€0.8% in H1, which would be encouraging for H2 and FY GM exceeding 59%. ONT noted that the company remains on track to achieve FY25 guidance for 20-23% LC Revenue growth and Gross margin of 59%. Given the strong H1 performance, we expect Consensus to remain towards the upper end of the FY25 guide of 23% LC which, with a 3% FX headwind, implies Revenues of €219m, c. 1% below latest BBG Consensus.James D GordonPharmaceuticals &amp; BiotechnologyPartners Group (OW)H1'25Revenues (CHFm)1,103.00Our H1 25E earnings expectations are broadly in line with consensus. We expect H1 25E revenues to stand in line with consensus, with management fees 1% below consensus being offset by slightly higher than consensus performance fees. Our H1 25E EBITDA forecast stands 1% above consensus on our expectation for slightly lower costs, but our EBIT forecast is in line with consensus as we expect a higher level of D&amp;A than consensus. Our H1 25E net profit estimate stands 1% below consensus on our expectation for a slightly lower financial result. We would highlight, however, that our 2025E net income estimate stands 4% below consensus driven mainly by a 4% lower management fee estimate than consensus, as we believe consensus may be underestimating the impact from a lower USDCHF at end June for H2 management fees. We expect the focus on the day to be on the outlook for management fee margins and performance fees in H2 25, as well as any colour on fundraising momentum, in particular around the evergreen programmes.Angeliki BariakariEBIT (CHFm)667.00Diversified Financials

CWCompany, Analyst, SectorEventKey MetricsJPMePreviewAnalyst CommentaryAshtead Group (NR)-Lushanthan Mahapatra, CFAQ1Sales ($ m)2,813.00LinkWe expect Ashtead to deliver a Q1'26 marginally ahead of consensus (Bloomberg), with our revenue/adj. EBITDA/adj. EPS are +1%/+2%/+2% ahead. We expect messaging to re-iterate that at the Q4'25 results and URI's Q2'25 results (covered by Tami Zakaria) who noted local construction activity is beginning to stabilise (albeit too early to see a recovery) and continued positivity on the pipeline of mega project activity. On the outlook, we expect guidance to be unchanged on FY26 rental revenue growth and gross capex. However, we see scope for the FCF guidance to be increased to $2.2-2.5bn (from $2.0-2.3bn currently) as a result of the cash benefit from the new US federal tax legislation. Overall, outside the FCF, we expect limited surprises with the upcoming results.Capital Goods

CWCompany, Analyst, SectorEventKey MetricsJPMPreviewAnalyst CommentaryM&amp;G plc (OW)S1Adjusted EarningE(EM)416.00LinkWe forecast double-digit operating profit growth in 1H25E, supported by operational leverage in the asset management business as a flat cost base compares to rising revenues, as well as a reduction in central costs due to lower interest payments. Net flows should improve for 1H25, mainly due to the life business given an assumed recovery PruFund net flows as well as better flows in Institutional Asset Management compared to 1H24. Adjusting for market movements, we expect flat AUM overall across the life and asset management businesses. We forecast a 227% Solvency II ratio (vs. 223% in FY24), reflecting 13ppts of positive capital generation in 1H25E, zero impact from market movements (as we assume that increased volatility offsets the impact of positive equity market performance), and a net negative 9ppt impact from other factors (dividends, a positive impact from DTA and tax).Farooq HanifOperational capital generation (Emn)389.00InsuranceLinkAfter a very strong start to the year (Q1 GGR growth of +8.2%), we see momentum in Q2 moderating slightly (JPME +4.8%), partly as a result of tough Betting comps (Euros related) and softer momentum in Lottery. On the profitability front, we expect a sequential improvement in EBITDA margin, modelled at 35.2% (vs 34.8% in Q1), up c.75bps y/y. The first quarter (we understand) was a bit of an anomaly, with margin coming in below the company's c.35% FY guidance, mainly as a result of stronger-than-expected competition during the quarter, which prompted higher marketing spend. This trend seems to be subsiding from Q2 onwards.OPAP SA (OW)Q2Q2 GGR growth (%)4.80LinkKaran PuriQ2 EBITDA margin (%)35.20Leisure, Hotels &amp; GamingLinkSwiss Life (UW)S1Adjusted profit from operations (CHF mn)824.00LinkWe are raising our estimates for operating profit by -0.5% over 2025-27, to allow for growth momentum in the French non-life business due to pricing trends, offset by slightly lower fee results due to lower growth trends in Germany and France. We expect operating profit to reduce by ~7% in 1H25E vs. 1H24 due to asset management. This is mainly due to an expectation of ~16% lower asset management operating profit in 1H25E vs. 1H24 due to lower non-recurring commission income. We are forecasting a ~5% growth in Gross Written Premiums in 1H25, as we expect the good momentum in GWP growth in 1Q25 to continue in 2Q25E. In Asset Management, we forecast CHF13bn of net new third party assets in 1H25. This follows the strong performance in 1Q25, but also reflects a strong level of inflows into lower margin 'index' strategies. We expect 9% lower cash remittances in 1H25E vs. 1H24, due to -CHF140mn one-off benefits last year. Swiss Life is set to deliver a Solvency II ratio of 194% at 1H25E (vs. 200% at 1Q25), mainly driven by 4ppts impact from the anticipated repayment of a hybrid debt.Farooq HanifTotal GWP (CHF mn)12,234.00Insurance
Thursday 04 September

CWCompany, Analyst, SectorEventKey MetricsJPMPreviewAnalyst CommentaryCVC (OW)H1'25Adjusted Revenue (Em)784.00Our H1 25 adjusted EBITDA forecast is 2% lower than the latestcompany-compiled consensus (which however precedes the Q2 25AuM update), reflecting a 2% lower forecasted top line, while ourestimate for total operating expenses is 1% lower than expectations.Our estimate for MFE is 3% lower than consensus, reflecting the 2%lower management fee forecast. As a reminder, CVC already reported Q2 25 AuM on August 14th. On the day, we believe investor focus will be on the outlook for PRE for both H2 25 and 2026. We also expectto hear more on the fundraising pipeline, with management pointing to several new strategy launches in Credit, Secondaries and Wealthover the next 12-18 months with the recent activity update.Angeliki BairaktariAdjusted EBITDA (Em)476.00Diversified Financials

CWCompany, Analyst, SectorEventKey MetricsJPMPreviewAnalyst CommentaryAshmore Group (UW)H1'25Reported total revenue (Em)78.10Our H2 25 forecast for adjusted EBITDA is 18% higher than thelatest company-compiled consensus (f29m vs. consensus f24m),reflecting higher estimated performance fees (f7m vs. consensusf2m) and a higher estimated FX benefit (f2.5m vs. consensus -f1.5m). As a reminder, Ashmore has already reported Q4 25 AuM on 14 July. On the day, investor focus will be on the outlook for FY26(especially in terms of expected net flows, management fee margin,and staff compensation) and Emerging Markets more generally,especially given the recent strong performance of key EM indices.Angeliki BairaktariAdjusted EBITDA (Em)28.60Diversified Financials

CWCompany, Analyst, SectorEventKey MetricsJPMcPreviewAnalyst CommentaryPhoenix Group (UW) Farooq Hanif InsuranceS1Adjusted operatingprofit (€mn)445.00LinkWe are reducing our 2025 operating profit estimate slightly and raising our 2026 forecast by ~1.5% and 2027E by ~0.5%. We think that Phoenix's cost-savings plan will allow it to get a little closer to its1.1bn 2026 operating profit guidance than we previously estimated,but with the impact of cost-savings a little more back-end loaded. As for 1H25E, we forecast a 24% growth in adjusted operating profit.Profit should be supported by further operating leverage benefits tothe margin in Pensions & Savings as well as the benefit of growth and better investment margins in the Retirement Solutions business. We anticipate double-digit growth in bulk annuity volumes to £2bn in1H25E vs. £1.7bn in 1H24. We expect operating cash generation of£0.7 billion, supported by recurring management actions that areconsistent with Phoenix's £0.5bn per year guidance. We also forecast a 172% Solvency II ratio at 1H25E vs. 172% at end-2024. Thisincludes a 9ppt benefit from capital generation net of new businessstrain, financing costs, pension costs and shareholder dividends, a4ppt negative impact from debt reduction, a 2ppt negative impact frommarket movements and a 2ppt negative impact from other investments in the business.Total cash generation(€mn)816.00

CWCompany, Analyst, SectorEventKey MetricsJPMcPreviewAnalyst CommentaryComputacenter (OW)Joseph GeorgeTech Software & IT ServicesS1Revenue (€m)Adj. PBT (€m)3,641.0081.00LinkWe are ~6% above Bloomberg consensus on Revenue (£3,641m vs£3,435m) and are in line with Bloomberg consensus on Adj. PBTDunelm Group plc (N)Georgina Johanan, ACAGeneral RetailFY25FY 26 PBT (€m)guidance213.00Dunelm has already reported Q4 25 sales and gross margin, andguided for FY 25 PBT to be in line with company cons for £210m atthe time of the update (JPMc £211m). Focus should therefore be oncurrent trading and on the FY 26 PBT outlook. We model FY 26 PBT of £213m, c.4% below company cons for £221m. Our lower profitforecast is driven by a lower top line assumption - we model FY 26sales +3.5% yoy vs cons c.+5%.Puig Brands (OW)Celine Pannuti, CFAHousehold & Personal CareProductS1H125 Group adj.EBITDA margin (%)H125 adj. diluted EPS(€)19.100.45LinkWe expect Group adj. EBITDA margin forecast of 19.1% in H125e,with a 20bps margin increase broadly aligned with FY guide. Thisperformance should be driven by a margin recovery in Makeup whileFashion and Fragrances should see some pressure due to higherA&P phasing in H125
Wednesday 10 September

CWCompany, Analyst, SectorEventKey MetricsJPMcPreviewAnalyst CommentaryAntin (N)Angeliki BairaktariDiversified FinancialsH1'25Total operating income148.00We expect to see limited progress both in terms of FPAuM as well as earnings in H1 25, given no incremental fundraising or exits taking place YTD. Our H1 25 adjusted EBITDA forecast is 24% lower H/H (no company-compiled consensus available at this stage), largely due to a lower top line (as H2 24 had benefitted from substantialcatch-up fees which are not being repeated) and incrementallyhigher costs as the company is preparing for the next fundraisingcycle. Our Q2 25 fee-paying AuM estimate of €21.4bn is flat Q/Q,reflecting no incremental fundraising or exits in the quarter. On theday, we believe investor focus will be on management's guidance for the upcoming fundraisings of MidCap II, Next Gen II, and Fund VI,as well as any plans for additional strategy launches.Adjusted EBITDA (€mn)78.00ABF (N)Georgina Johanan, ACAGeneral RetailFY25 PreCloseTradingUpdatePrimark EBIT margin (%)Primark H2 LFL (% yoy)-0.50LinkWe forecast Primark H2 LFL of -0.5% (H1-2.5%), supported bymore favourable weather in the UK. With our LFL being within theguided range (JPMc FY 25 LFL -1.4% vs guide for -1% to -3%), we think there is little risk to FY 25 Primark margin guidance for broadly flat yoy. Furthermore we would note that management commented at the H1 25 results that it had "assumed some unmitigated cost in the second half of this year" from US tariffs (when the rate on China was set at 145%). We think this implies at least some 10s of bps ofsavings vs what was accounted for in guidance. We model FY 25Primark EBIT margin of 11.7% (FY24: 11.7%) and EBIT of €1,126m (in-line with BBG cons for €1,123m). Looking ahead, we expectmanagement to provide an initial view on the FY 26 Primark margin. We estimate at least 100bps of gross margin tailwinds from external factors (FX and freight, although we think the latter is much moredifficult to model reliably). On the other hand, pre-mitigations, weexpect 40bps of annualised pressure from US tariffs. Below grossmargin, the ongoing living wage increase in the UK is unhelpful inthe context of our expectation for an ongoing LFL decline. Combined with the potential need for investment in price perception, we thinkmanagement is unlikely to guide for an improvement in the Primarkmargin in FY 26 and we think guidance will instead be for a broadlyflat margin. Separately, worth noting that investor questions at theresults could focus on whether there is a need for price investment,and competitive environment (particularly amid the roll out ofInditex's value concept, Lefties).Q2 '25Q2 Sales ex-FX yoy (%)Q2 EBIT (€m)6.001,912.00LinkGeorgina Johanan, ACAGeneral RetailThe group entered the quarter with sales growth (1 May to 9 Jun)+6% yoy ex-FX. Since then trends across key clothing markets thatwe track have been mixed. Comments from Zalando suggest that Jul has improved (with the retailer reaching sales growth of +HSD% vs+5% in Q2). Whilst we think at least some of any Jul improvementwould have been discount driven, we expect Inditex (whose business model supports a stricter full price stance) to have been supportedby a halo effect. For Q2 overall we therefore model steady salesgrowth of +6% ex-FX. We also expect a focus on current trading(Aug and start Sep). For Q3 overall we model sales ex-FX +6%.Within this we expect Aug also +6% but Sep +4% to reflect that Sep-24 was particularly strong across the whole market. Below top linewe look for broadly flat EBIT yoy, in line with the Q1 trend, withgrowth weighed by FX. More broadly, we expect growth initiatives to remain on track and for management to provide more detail on plansfor the (value end) Lefties concept.

The Company reporting dates can be Confirmed, Estimated or Tentative. +CW - Positive catalyst watch, -CW- Negative catalyst watchCatalyst Watch is our short-term conviction indicator for our coverage universe. It is an optional indicator our research analysts can apply to a stock in their coverage into a specific event in order to articulate short-term positivity or caution based on near-term fundamentals. As such, it can differ from the analysts' published ratings, which are sector relative and longer term in nature.Source: J.P. Morgan estimates and Bloomberg Finance L.P.

Clients tell us that their most valuable counterparts are those who successfully differentiate signal from noise. Aimed to provide clarity around the particularly busy periods of reporting and upcoming events, Catalyst Watch is our short- term conviction indicator for our coverage universe. It is an optional indicator our research analysts can apply into a specific event in order to articulate short term positivity or caution based on near- term fundamentals. As such, it can differ from the analysts' published ratings, which are sector relative and longer term in nature.

TickerCompany NameCatalystCatalyst DateRatingRationaleLinkVOE AVvoestalpine AGEU steel import reviewSep-2025 (TBC)NGiven its high European earnings exposure, the company is well placed to benefit from any potential inflationary impact on EU steel prices from the European Commission's upcoming review. Our CYQ3/Q4 EBITDA estimates are 3%/14% above consensus.LinkVOLVB SSVolvo AB3Q25 results17-Oct-2025OWWe expect the company to benefit from better capacity utilisation and earnings momentum in Europe, net inventories, new product launches in North America, and a high local US footprint. JPMo Group adjusted EBIT 10%/3% above Bloomberg consensus for 25/26E.LinkSW USSmurfit WestRock PLC3Q25 results30-Oct-2025OWManagement guidance on pricing is conservative, in our view, and we anticipate price tailwinds to come in Q3/Q4. JPMo 3Q25 EBITDA is c. 1% ahead of BBG consensus.LinkIAG SMInternational Consolidated Airlines Group SA3Q25 results7-Nov-2025OWWe see the potential for continued pricing outperformance to lead to consensus upgrades, driven by positive transatlantic trends. JPMo FY25 EBIT is 6% above BBG consensus.LinkSIE GRSiemens AGCMD9-Dec-2025OWThe Healthineers holding should be addressed at the CMD, marking a significant step in the portfolio simplification effort. Our 25E/26E EPS estimates are 3%/7% ahead of company-complied consensus.LinkSN/LNSmith &amp; Nephew PLCCMDDec-2025 (TBC)OWWe see compelling risk-reward for the event, which stands out to us in a CMD-heavy H2. We anticipate new three-year guidance, with trading margins in the 21-22% range (vs. FY28 BBG consensus of 20.6%).Link

TickerCompany NameCatalystCatalyst DateRatingRationaleLinkLHA GRDeutsche Lufthansa AG3Q25 results30-Oct-2025UWOur analysis suggests unfavourable transatlantic trends, including negative weighted passenger volume growth in Lufthansa's core markets. JPMo FY25 EBIT is 9% below BBG consensus.LinkSCT LNSoftcat PLCFY25 results22-Oct-2025NOur analysis suggests that the one-off nature of large deals booked in FY25 is not reflected in consensus EBIT growth expectations. Our FY26 estimates sit c.4% below consensus, reflecting downside risk to management guidance.Link8TRA GRTraton SE3Q25 results29-Oct-2025NWe anticipate that negative volume effects at Scania and FX headwinds will continue to pressure margins in the second half; our 25/26E adj. EBIT forecasts are 7%/9% below consensus.Link
Source: Company reports and J.P. Morgan estimates.

Analyst Certification: The Research Analyst(s) denoted by an "AC" on the cover of this report certifies (or, where multiple Research Analysts are primarily responsible for this report, the Research Analyst denoted by an "AC" on the cover or within the document individually certifies, with respect to each security or issuer that the Research Analyst covers in this research) that: (1) all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect the Research Analyst's personal views about any and all of the subject securities or issuers; and (2) no part of any of the Research Analyst's compensation was, is, or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed by the Research Analyst(s) in this report. For all Korea-based Research Analysts listed on the front cover, if applicable, they also certify, as per KOFIA requirements, that the Research Analyst's analysis was made in good faith and that the views reflect the Research Analyst's own opinion, without undue influence or intervention.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex- Australia and ex- India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
